sp.p: Why Jeremy, you rogue, no further yet? my Lord's a departing, and my Ladies diſtracted, and ſhe ſwears that ſhe would not for a thouſand pound but my Lord ſhould go out of the world skilfully, and die under a Doctor.

sp.speaker: 1 Meſſ.
sp.p: But the Doctor won't come till he hath viewed a Patient hard by: there he ſtands; if you will perſwade him, you may.

sp.speaker: 2 Meſſ.
sp.p: 'S death, ſtand diſputing in a deſperate occaſion? lend's a hand.

sp.speaker: Gam.
sp.p: Help, help! murder, rape, murder!

sp.speaker: 2 Meſſ.
sp.p: No, it is you would murder by delaies.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Gentlemen, why Gentlemen! I command you in the Kings name, what do you meane, a riot?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: They meane, it ſhould ſeeme forſooth, to carry him bodily away.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Ha, carry him? hath grief made me ſo tame a foole as to let Rogues run away with him?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: I-feaking, forſooth, they were cowards by his running.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I muſt home, and ſee how affairs go: perſwaſions in the end may work upon her; In the meane time, good Sir, informe your ſelfe of ſome skilfull Artiſt that is acquainted with theſe Lunacies.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: If London afford one, forſooth, nor penny nor pains will I ſpare. I am down-right honeſt, and Blunt to an inch.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I truſt to you; pray let us ſee you often.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: I ſhall make bold to trouble you, forſooth, as they ſay.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
You know you are welcome, Sir; be vigilant and
carefull, if you love her, it concernes you.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Fear not, forſooth: Sir, I will be as watchfull as an Owle by Moone-light.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I Wonder I have no anſwer; art ſure my letter was delivered?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Am I ſure I live?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Then me thinks an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: So I think too, and ſhould my ſelf expect it
From any man that doth pretend to love:
But he's a meere Court-butterfly, that buzzes
And flies about each warme beame of beauty
He encounters.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: He courted me with ſuch a vehemencie of ardor, as if his heart were loves furnace.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: The like he did to me, to the ſame height
As if he had been to Court an Empreſs:
But 'tis a cuſtom now, a common one,
For every gallant to be thus in love;
To court each female they encounter with,
Pretending love to all, truely to none:
A kinde of breeding, mother, newly landed,
To exerciſe mens wits, and trie womens
Credulity.—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: But can'ſt thou think it poſſible (Acuta)
That Ticket ſhould diſſemble? I have known
Many, whoſe words held no Intelligence
With their heart, but never any yet
Could change their countenance unto their ſpeech;
Expreſſing ſuch an ardor in his eyes,
As if they were loves torches; and ſuch a
Senſibility of feeling in his words,
As if his heart were pierc'd, or rather chang'd
With love into one ſubſtance.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: Piſh, this is nothing, Mother; for there are
Far greater Artiſts in this new-found love
Now moſt in faſhion and moſt A la mode:
Ticket's but yet a Novice.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: It is ſo incredible, I can't believe't;
I thought my ſelf a Miſtreſs in this art,
But were this true, we muſt no more compare
With men for diſſimulation —

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: It were too great a madneſs: for they are
As far, in that, beyond us, as in ſtrength:
By them, 'tis thought a virtue to deceive,
Eſpecially our Sex; they glory in't,
As in plurality of Miſtreſſes,
A ſcore, or ſo, from which, to eaſe their luſt,
They this day ſelect one, next another,
So for halfe a dozen; the reſt are fed
With airy complements, and ſuch flie-blown
Oaths and proteſtations as have been
Thrice pawn'd for ſix-pence, and twice forfeited.
Oh Mother, did you know but mans deceit,
You would not wonder why the Antients
Pictur'd Faith and Truth like women.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: That's the leaſt: but how you ſhould reach
Theſe myſteries, exacts my admiration;
One that I ſtill bred underneath my wing,
That hardly e're convers'd with Gentleman
Beyond Gliſterpipe, or the Deputy
Of the Ward, at a Hall-feaſt.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: Alaſs, good Mother, you do many things
My Father little dreames of; are not you
As liable to be deceiv'd by me?
You know not how learn'd your Acuta's grown,
Deep read in the hearts of men.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I'll be thy Diſciple; come, read me a leſſon.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: I will; hear then, and edifie, Mother.
There be five ſorts of lovers; onely two
That can be truſted; the reſt liſtn'd to,
But not believ'd: firſt, the inconſtant lover;
He for a time doth love intirely,
Untill a fairer object he doth meet
More pleaſing to his eye: this man we ſtile
A lover upon ſight; for unto each
New face, he ſacrifices his falſe heart.
Next, your vaine-glorious boaſting lover;
He is dangerous: for when he cannot
Lie with your perſon, he'll be ſure to do it
With your reputation, and
Multiply the ſmalleſt atomes of your
Favours to mountains, by the glaſs of his
Diſcourſe. The third, a Platonick lover,
One that pretends a ſpirituall mixtion,
To facilitate the incorporating of ſenſe:
He's a kinde of Satan in a white robe,
That with a commandation of your ſoule,
Extracts the quinteſſence of your body.
The fourth is a ſimple jealous lover;
Him you may work unto what forme you pleaſe:
His ſuperfluity of love, makes him
Jealous; and his ſimplicity will not
Let him know of whom: He's conſtant, and
As obedient as you'd wiſh a man;
Created for ſuch women as would weare
The breeches. The fifth's the conſtant lover;
But of them there are ſo few, and fewer
That can character them unto their worth,
That I may well ſpare mine.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: But Daughter, where's your lover A la mode?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: He's not a perfect ſpecies, a mothy mungrell kinde, compos'd of the inconſtant and Platonick; I treated of him before.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Thou did'ſt, and learnedly; prethee who's thy inſtructreſs?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: A Lady here hand by, that hath the art
To deale with all theſe ſeverall kindes of lovers
In their own humour.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I long for her acquaintance: let's thither.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: You wo'n't repent the voyage.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I'll but fetch my hoods.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: So, I have almoſt put her off the ſent
Of that musk'd Gallants perſum'd love; could I
But keep them at a diſtance now, or my
Self near them when they ſhall diſcourſe;
It will confirm my Mother woo's for me,
And hinder Ticket from diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: THis is the houſe, deare Ticket; and ſee where comes it's ornament and choiceſt furniture.

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.p: A heavenly compos'd beauty: Prethee preſent me to her.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: All in good time; ſhe moves towards us. Lady, preſuming upon the greatneſs of your mercy, I take the boldneſs to preſent this friend of mine to your acquaintance, a Gentleman and Traveller.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: Two good qualities: but I want ne're a Groome,
Though you want much civility, to intrude into
My houſe upon ſo ſmall acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: We have us'd too much reſpect, and I believe
More ceremony, then your common trade
Hath been acquainted with: for otherwiſe
You'd better underſtand how to returne
Civilities.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: Y'are a pretty Gentleman, your friend ſayes,
And a Traveller; you had done well to have
Brought home more manners, and leſs impudence.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Madam, we came to love, honour, and ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Prethee forbear; fawn not upon her, like
A Spaniel newly beaten: learn of me,
I'll ſhew thee ſtraight the way to handle ſuch
Peeviſh diſſimulation, that beares
A fine appearing gloſs of ſanctity;
But fret and trie it thus, it falls to pieces.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Keep off, rude Companion.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: So, this ſmall parcell of hypocriſie
Whileſt you ſtand at diſtance, ſhaking and
Quivering like an Anabaptiſt dipt
In January, appears chaſte and virtuous:
But tumble her and touze her thus!

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Out, ſhameleſs impudence!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: You'll quickly finde the brittle ſtuffe ſhe's made
sp.l: on.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Sir, If you won't be civill, I ſhall call thoſe ſhall make you ſo: do you take this for a common receptacle?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: The commoneſt thing in London, except
The Owner. Come, faith, be not ſo nice; to me
'Tis needleſs; I am ver'ſt in the world, know
What belongs to it: no young heire, Lady,
To be caught with the baite of ſeeming modeſty
In the nooze of wedlock; to me you may
Appeare a woman without danger. Come,
Keep your niceneſs for ſome home-bred Gallant,
Deny him the favour of your hand, whil'ſt
Knowing men thus reape the Nectar of
Your lips, and crop the harveſt of your choiceſt
Pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: See, in foure minutes he's arriv'd at more
Then foure years could purchaſe me; he ha's the
Trick on't; for when ſhe frown'd, as if the anger
Of all her ſex were contracted in her browes,
He charg'd her boldly, and upon the firſt
Aſſault he won her to more favour, then
All my large expence of time and treaſure could
Purchaſe me. I never was ſo mov'd before:
Oh my heart! I thought thou had'ſt been of a
Tougher mould: love ne'r could work upon
Thee, and ſhall jealouſie make thee her triumph?
No, heart, thou ſhalt break firſt. But I'll withdraw:
Halfe an houres conſideration is to me ſo catholical
An antidote againſt the poiſon of love, as the
Whole Colledge can't preſcribe a better.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Madam, You ever oblige me yours; and now
I know the reaſon of your ſtrict behaviour, do
Approve it, nor ſhall you ever finde me negligent,
In what may leaſt concern your preſent ſervice,
Or future fortunes. —

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: Your promiſes are noble, like your ſelf;
And they no ſooner ſhall be put in act,
Then I be ready to ſerve you, in ſuch
Manner, as modeſty will not allow
Me dreſs in words. —

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Madam, I'll take your meaning for your words:
Both are ſo plain, I cannot miſs the ſenſe:
Nor you a Husband long, if I have wit,
Or the leaſt art to compaſs your deſignes.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: I dare not queſtion either, yet it will
Require much of both, e're we can bring
Him to a ſenſe of love, much more to think
Of that ſame Gobbling (as he termeth it)
Matrimony. —

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Leave that to me, though I think Monſieur Rant
A beaten ſouldier in the war of love:
One, that hath as little faith in women,
As in Atheiſts; a deep-read ſcholar in
The deceits and ſubtilties of the ſex:
Yet all theſe conſiderations can't
Make me doubt or fear the enterprize;
Which cannot in difficulty equall
My deſire to ſerve you, or will to oblige you.
But I waſte time in words, whil'ſt I ſhould put
In actions my deſigns: let's firſt contrive
How we may bring our ſtratagem about:
He muſt be taken in the humour, Lady,
That I know; and his are commonly ſo
Short lived, they'll hardly laſt
The Ceremony out.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: Then it muſt be his drunken humor; that will
Laſt till he be ſober.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Well remembred: for his loving humour alwayes
Attends it; and two humours being of the plurall
Number, will eaſier admit of the plurality of yours.
But how ſhall we bring him to this rare paſs?
For he's very temperate.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: Bring him you hither, then let me alone; we'll
Drink healths to all the obliging Ladies in Town.
I have good brains; his breeding will oblige him to
Pledge me. I muſt ſtill help you out.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Moſt have need of helping in, Lady; but let that
Paſs: expect within this half hour your Gallant,
And then with your aſſiſtance, (for without you
I am nothing) I do not doubt to get you a
Covering for your veniall treſpaſſes.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: However, you'll oblige me; I judge not ſervices by
The event. The news?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Miſtriſs Acuta with another Lady are come to waite upon you. —

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: I attend them preſently.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: 'Tis time I were about your enterprize: your ſervant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: Your ſervant, Monſieur Ticket. — Oh theſe men,
How many wayes they ſtrive to compaſs their
Baſe wills! ſometimes they flatter us: with thoſe
I can deale pretty well: for I believe
As ſeldome what they ſay, as they do ſpeak
The true and ſincere meaning of their heart:
Others do ſeek with Jewells, and rich gifts,
For to corrupt our chaſtity; and buy
With droſs a Jewell beyond price; yet theſe
My poverty would ſeek, did not virtue
Supply my meane defect: yet I am forc'd
To play the hypocrite, tho' the wrong way;
Appearing far leſs virtuous then I am,
Remaining virtuous amidſt incontinence.
For ſuch a price I ſet upon the thing
Moſt men do aime at, as hath frighted hence
All vulgar chapmen; others with ſcornes and niceneſs
I have daunted ſo, they dare not urge
A word of love beyond Matrimony.
Thus becoming Miſtriſs of their hearts, their purſe
Is ſtill at my command; yet this contents
Not me; though I be honeſt, I am thought
A whore: beſides, they may grow inſolent,
Witneſs my own brother, though his travell
Hath blotted from his memory my face,
His naturall wildeneſs can admit no change;
For had I not compli'd with his looſe thoughts,
The looſeſt ſtrangers had ſeem'd Saints to him:
But I'll finde time to let him know his fault,
Which with much willingneſs I could forgive,
If he effect my wiſh in Rants chaſte love.
I would be gladly Married, 'tis moſt true,
She's hard put to't, that doth begin to woo.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: SWeet Miſtriſs, do not proſecute the phrenſies.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: Why do'ſt diſturb the ſpirit, wicked tempter? but tribulations muſt be borne with patience and meekneſs.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: I had rather beare a handſome young man, as old as I am; there's the beſt tribulation in Chriſtendome.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: Do'ſt think we are not ſtray'd in the way that leads to the Meeting-Houſe?

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: What, to S. Antlins?

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: Antlin, thou reprobate! the word Saint is ſuperſtitious, and idolatrous; verily I do abominate thy company,
sp.l: for thou art poſſeſt with the ſpirit of prophaneneſs, yea, the very ſpirit of ſuperſtition.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Poore woman! how ſhe's altered, rather beſotted to this Lunacy! could I but take her a little off the ſpirit, and
sp.l: give her a ſmack of the fleſh, there were ſome hopes. See how ſhe turnes up the eggs of her eyes, like the figure of
Abram in Sand's ſhow!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Save you, Siſter; I profeſs I am glad, and rejoyce in ſincerity, that the ſpirit hath mov'd you thus early to the
sp.l: convention of the godly.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Mercy on me! he come? now am I more timorous and fearefull then a Hare that the Hounds had newly caught by the
sp.l: buttocks.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But Siſter, oh that I ſhould ſee this, that I ſhould ſee you accompanied with the wicked thus! oh! that I ſhould ſee
sp.l: you accompanied with the reprobate, with the very Publican: by yea and nay it is not well.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p:
How I tremble! he looks as if his zeale would tranſpierce
me: there's never a truer Quaker in Wapping, then I at this preſent.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: Verily, brother, the Serpent will purſue me in the ſhape of vanity, tho' I look upon her with the eyes of
sp.l: Reformation.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My zeale doth foame, yea and boile againſt her: I do abominate antiquity, ſhe looks like the very clay of the beaſt;
sp.l: I profeſs, like a very tradition.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Now am I in a worſe taking, then a Baily in an Inns of Court.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: Good brother, pacifie thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My zeal's too ſtrong; yea, I am tranſported with indignation againſt that Monaſtickhood; and thus do I tread the I
sp.l: doll under my feet.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Oh! good Sir, my hood, my hood!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Doſt thou ſpeak in defence of abomination? aſſiſt me zeale to chaſtiſe her vanity.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Never were Lovers put to ſuch hard ſhifts
To gaine a moment for entertainment
Of their lawfull loves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Never, my Coelia: but yet the pleaſure
I enjoy by looking on that face,
The harmonious Muſick of thy voice, joyn'd
With the melody of agreeing hearts,
So far exceed in bliſs the paine ſuſtain'd,
That like a Mother having born a ſon,
I ſtraight forget, when I enjoy thee (ſweet)
Th' anguiſh and affliction of thy abſence.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: And I, in abſence nouriſh ſtill a hope
Of ſeeing thee, and preſent feare to looſe thee.
My love's ſo ſtrictly wedded to my grief,
They know no ſeparation: if that
At any time they reliſh joy, hope is
The parent to that happy childe, which I
Can never foſter in my breaſt, till it become
Your Pillow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh that happy day (Coelia) that day
Of happineſs, when will it come? is fate
So rigid to deny the knowledge? or Gods
Become ſo mercileſs, to divide two hearts
So much united? or is it their feare
Love ſhould become on earth ſuch an example
As heaven could not parallell?

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Deare Sir, reclaime your paſſions; our time
Is ſhort, not to be loſt in complement.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Can time be loſt, that is ſo well employ'd?
And in thy ſweet ſociety is mine.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Nor do I think it ſo; I could dwell here
An age to heare thee ſpeak: but fate denies
That happineſs as yet; therefore 'twere fit
Love found out ſome invention, by which
We might more frequently enjoy each others
Company, till time compleate our happineſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your admonition's timely: I was loſt
In faire affection's maze; ſo tranſported
With my preſent happineſs, that I thought
It might be laſting to eternity. —
But waken'd from this dreame, I do perceive
The houre-glaſs of my happineſs run out:
And how this baſe diſguiſe can recruit it,
To me appears a riddle.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: 'Tis thus far uſefull; for it diſguiſes
Both our loves, and keeps my father from
Wedding me to Blunt, a man I hate, more
Then the worſt diſeaſe the worſt of women
Ever merited.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But we might chooſe ſome other: what thinks my love of ſeigning her ſelf ſick, and having me ſent for as your
sp.l: Phyſitian?

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: The cure would be too ſudden, and my joy diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: With eaſe you might diſſemble both. —

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: 'Twere eaſier far, to force a feigned joy,
Then ſtifle ſuch a reall one: howe're,
I'll trie my utmoſt art.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Do ſo, my Coelia, for I Prophetize,
That this device may meet with good ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Heavens grant it: you know I need not
Feigne my ſelf ſick, diſtempered, ill at eaſe;
Thy abſence ſtill to me is a diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which with my preſence I'll oft mitigate,
And from thy lips drink a preſerving Balme,
That in thy abſence like an Antidote,
Shall keep me from th' infection of deſpaire.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: I think my love's already a Phyſitian;
For he is perfect in their Dialect.
With earneſt longings, I'll expect to heare
The iſſue of your project: don't abuſe
My expectation with too long delayes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Life of my ſoule! aſſure your ſelf I will not.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Y'ave play'd too long the Truant, 'tis time
You were about it. —

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I cannot leave you to go home alone:
Nor dare I wait upon you: part of the way
I will accompany you, untill we meet
Matrona; and then —

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Then we muſt part; I underſtand thy look:
Sighs are ſentences in loves Table-book.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.l: WHat, are they gone, or retir'd onely
Into a Coupling houſe! Theſe Familiſts
Are the hypocritical'ſt Letchers in
A Kingdom; their motives of the ſpirit
Alwayes end in the fleſh. Perhaps he hath
Taken her in to catechize; but ſhould
His zealous doctrine begin with an increaſe
And multiply, twenty to one but he'll
See the fruit on't within nine moneths, or ſo.
Well, if theſe precize meeting-houſes be
Not the ſtaples of Letchery, and the
Heralds office of Cuckoldry; there is not
A grain of luſt in the compoſition
Of a woman of my years. 'Tis ſo; I begin
To ſmell a notorious Letcher under
That lenten cauſe: I would not be a Bawde
Without my fee. Well, Monſieur Purity,
If thou doſt infuſe unwholeſome doctrine
In thy new Proſelyte, and make her ſwell,
Thou art the moſt hypocriticall Villain,
That ever made Religion a Cloake
For luſt and treaſon: But here they come.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: Yonder's my Governeſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I take my leave, tho' with as ſad a heart
As vanquiſht Kings part with their raviſh't Scepter:
Yet mid'ſt our griefs, this feeble hope remains;
Joyes are ſtill ſweeteſt, after greateſt pains:
And every one this maxime will approve,
That expectation is the food of love.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Oh! but fruition is affections life;
A Maid's ne'r happy till ſhe be a Wife.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And Man's imperfect till he leads a Bride,
A halfe-fac'd Medall ſtamp't but on one ſide.
Why ſhould we then through feare, defer this Match,
VVhich would to both ſuch happineſs afford,
Render us perfect in each others love,
Or rather with perfection crowne our loves?
Let's to the Temple: why ſhould our body part,
VVhen mutuall vowes have married our heart?

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Oh Philoſtratus, yield not ſo much to paſſion,
Leſt you give me occaſion to believe you
An enemy to virtue and obedience.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have done: but ſince love was cauſe of my offence, I can't deſpaire of pardon.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: I can afford you nothing with more willingneſs,
Except my ſelf; which if you'd ſoon obtaine, ſtraight
Put in act what lately we deſign'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Y'ave put new heat into me, I flie to the performance.
Farewell, and pray for the ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: My prayers are never wanting. — Come, Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Now to my diſcovery: good godly Sir, receive the prayers of one, that hath wandred long in the path of ignorance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Good woman, your Miſtriſs is gone.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: And would be willingly inſtructed in the right way.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Pox, what ſhall I do with her? I have no time to looſe in catechizing.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Oh liſten to my Reformation, the humble deſire I have to be inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have it — VVoman, before I can receive thee into the ſociety of the godly, thou muſt make a publick
sp.l: recantation of all thy errors, and ſet three Congregationall Meetings upon the ſtoole of repentance.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: And pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Make not an Idoll of me; no creature may be worſhipt: but follow me, and ſee you prove no hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.l: I care not what I prove, ſo I diſcover
The ſecret ſubject of your cloſe diſcourſe,
VVhich I ſuſpect already; but I'll after:
If it ſucceed, I ſhall grow fat with laughter.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: MOnſieur Ticket.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Your ſervant, Sir; you did bravely to give
Your friend the ſlip, when you had ingag'd him
In ſo perilous an adventure.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: I faith I left you not, untill the Fort
VVas yielded, and you in full poſſeſſion;
I ſtood but as a Cypher, vowing my own
Shame, after ſo many nice refuſalls
And puts off, ſaw the Fort taken, upon
The firſt aſſault; ſhe's a very woman,
And as ſuch beſtowes her favours.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Y'ave ſpoken much in little, Sir; but I admire
You could be Maſter of ſo large a Faith,
As ever to believe her niceneſs more,
Then a faire verniſh ſet upon her luſt.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: I did and do believe it reall.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: And that ſhe meerly ſtood upon the ſum
By her excis'd upon her Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: That's part of my beliefe too; and how e're it was
Your fate ſo to reduce her, our firſt onſet
Promiſed but little comfort. —

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: The faireſt omen in the world: give me
A nice behaviour, a rigid Damzell;
For they that do upon themſelves impoſe
A ſtrictneſs of beaviour, more then uſuall,
VVould thereby ſeeme, what really they are not,
Honeſt; and by their niceneſs in carriage
Attract th' ignorant to their devotions —
VVhil'ſt to others expert, and knowing their
Hypocriſies, they appeare as prodigall
Of their favours, as Politicians are
Of their promiſes they meane not to performe:
And more open, then Oyſters at a full tide.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: I muſt not yield to your opinion, Sir,
Experience plainly ſhews the contrary,
That women are by ſome hid ſympathy
In nature, conſtrain'd to love and fancy
Some few particular perſons, and ſhun
Others, though of far greater merit.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Flat hereſie, there are inclin'd to all,
In their natures moſt inſatiable;
And if to ſome they do appeare more ſtrict,
Their Politick rules of Government conſtrain it;
For they're a Commonwealth among themſelves,
And ſquare their actions out by policie:
Their Maxims teach them when to appeare free,
VVhen nice, when amorous, and when wanton:
Free unto ſuch, whom they ſuppoſe too wiſe,
Or too much lovers of their liberty
To enter into bondage; and nice to thoſe
They fancy maſters of ſimplicity
Enough to take them for their VVives, binding
Themſelves firmely to believe them honeſt,
Whil'ſt they ſhall ſee no other; or if they do,
Their hornes in time may make a circular
Compaſs (like the Rams) about their brows, ſo
Serve for ſpectacles to rectifie their eye-ſight.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Ha, ha! this is a good raillerie.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thou'rt ſo incredulous! Piſh, I can bring thee authentick proofe that all I ſay is Canonicall.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: It muſt be ocular, good Ticket; for leſs
Shall never alter my beliefe: Do I
Not know my ſelf as meriting as thee,
Thy travells ſet aſide? as full of courtſhip,
And no leſs Maſter of audacity?
Nor need my form, my ſtrength, my ſtature, or
My breeding yield precedency to any;
Tho' I confeſs, you do in moſt of theſe excell:
And for my purſe, it has been as open
To that woman as to my ſelf: yet I
Could never from her yet obtain a kiſs,
Not purchaſt at a double rate: and thou
Upon a ſmall or no acquaintance, to
Be admitted as freely to her lips,
As to a Church, for ought I know, unto
Her bed, Pox 'tis a fate, a plaguy deſtinie.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Heate not your ſelfe ſo much; I heare you, man,
And cannot chooſe but laugh at your ſo fixt
Atheiſticall beliefe; from which, if you
Have any grace, I'll withdraw you: therefore
Know, this woman, this nice preciſe woman,
Hath ſollicited me with earneſtneſs
To procure thee to be her husband.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Thou doſt but jeſt?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Refuſe me elſe: and upon this condition, I have
Her promiſe of a nights lodging in reverſion.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: And could'ſt thou conceale this, to betray thy friend?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: No, I came with reſolution to have told thee all, but that thy paſſion caſt upon me another argument.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Did ſhe think me ſuch an Afs?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: She did: let me intreat thy patience.
I promis'd to effect her will; at which
She ſeem'd tranſported with her joy: then ſtreight
She laid the plot, that I ſhould bring thee to her,
Where Wine ſhould be prepar'd to make thee drunk;
And in that fit a Parſon ready for
To Marry you: Now I have a device
To turne the plot wholly upon her ſelfe.
But here the Ladies come, hark in your eare.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: I Wiſh the meanes of my fortunes would have afforded you an entertainment equall unto your worths: but what in that
sp.l: was ſcant, your welcome muſt ſupply.

sp.speaker: Clitt.
sp.p: There needs no apologie, Madam, where the entertainment and entertainer both appear'd ſo excellent: for my part, I
sp.l: pity my misfortune, in being ſo long ignorant of your worth, and barr'd your rich acquaintance, and therein envy my
daughters happineſs.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Good mother, let's leave complement, leſt we become ſubjects of mirth for thoſe eaves dripping gallants.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: So, 'twill be excellent: the Ladies ſpie us; we'll upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.p: Your wiſhes upon you, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: Then you would not be ſo near me.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Not more near then welcome.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: Who told you ſo, good Squire?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: My ſelf, good Madam; I need no Tutor.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: I thought ſo, that made you in the wrong: for he that teacheth himſelf, hath none of the wiſeſt maſters.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: The fool thanks you, Madam. — Lady, ſhall I hold fairer quarter here?

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: Nay, if you ſhift quarters ſo oft, I fear you are hardly in a poſture of defence, much leſs to vanquiſh.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: You mean not to aſſault me, Lady?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: Nor be aſſaulted by you: fare ye well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Quick and ſhort.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: This 'tis to change: ſeldome comes the better.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: If the beſt be ſo bad, Love defend me from the worſt.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: Come, come, as bad as we are, you could make A ſhift with the worſt of us.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: She's pleaſant and free: I like it rarely;
I'll follow the humour cloſe:

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.l: If that you doubt one ſyllable of what
My tongue ſo largely hath expreſt, you do
Me the moſt ignoble wrong that faithful
Lover ever yet ſuſtain'd. Oh, Madam,
Wer't poſſible you could conceive my love,
The tortures and the pains I do ſuſtain
For you (dear miſtriſs) the continual ſighs,
And floods of tears that trickle from my eyes,
Like to another deluge; drowning all
My joyes at once, except the comfort of
Your name, your ſacred name, which all amidſt
My extaſies of love, I call upon;
You could not be ſo cruel, ſo obdurate.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p:
Alaſs, I pitty him: can all this love be feign'd? and
yet I fear it is, elſe he could not ſo far have ſlighted me, as not returne an anſwer to my Letter.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: Remember that, and ben't deluded.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Can't all theſe teares diſſolve that marble heart,
Able to melt the Adamant it ſelfe,
And make it pliable as wax i'th' Sun,
Apt to take any forme? oh that your heart
VVere ſo, ſo fit for loves impreſſion!

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Pray no more; You diſturb your ſelf, and me.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.l: A painted fire may delight the eye,
Or flutter afar off the deceiv'd hopes
Of a cold frozen wretch; but when approach't,
Affords no heat, nor light: ſuch is your love,
In firſt appearance fair, and paſſionate;
Your tongue ſeems full of heat: but Sir, your heart
Is like a frozen clod of ice, floating
Upon diſſimulations ſea, and fails
All ſuch as tread upon that ſlippery pavement.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Madam, Your Daughters ſpeech doth add ſuch Seas
Of griefe unto my ſoule, that now I finde
My ſelfe but in a bad condition
Farther to plead my love; pray think upon't;
Such love comes ſeldome, and ought not to be refus'd.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: VVhat were I beſt do?

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.l: If that you have a minde to looſe your ſelfe,
And more then is your ſelfe, your honor, confide
In that inconſtant man.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I'll never think on him.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: Study to forget him: ſee, he's courting Aſtutia.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: They're very merry; we'll mix company.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: VVith me, Lady?

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.l: Yes, Sir: I underſtand you court me by Atturney,
And therefore out of pitty I informe you, your
Love goes many miles about, nor does't become
A Gentleman to court the parents liking firſt,
And ſo impoſe a violence upon a Virgins love.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Madam, I muſt confeſs my love's to you;
And yet I hope I have not far tranſgreſs'd
By courting you in the perſon of your
Mother; ſince 'tis according to her own
Directions; and I believ't, with your approbation.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.l: There's no ſuch matter, Sir; for I expect
Peculiar addreſſes to my ſelfe,
From any man that hopes to make me his.
You did begin that way.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: All ſhall be mended, Lady.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: That at your own diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Three Ladies is too much odds. I was well match't before.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Take courage, man; I'm come for to relieve thee.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: 'Twas well you did; for he was talking here,
To match his wit; and in good truth 'twas ſuch
A tired Jade, that none could match it.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Then 'twas a matchleſs wit.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: Or rather, there was no wit to be match't.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Good Ladies, let my wit alone, and make
Uſe of my body, that will match ye all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he!

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: If it were dipt in brimſtone, it were a rare match.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: To fire all the farthing-candles in Towne.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Or what is of leſs value, Woman.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: An excellent halfe-farthing jeſt!

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: Had it been leſs, it had been worth juſt nothing.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: Not worth the wart upon his noſe.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Y'are very pleaſant, Ladies, with me and my
Noſe; but I have a better thing at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: But is it ſound, Sir?

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: A queſtion well urg'd.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: I warrant you, Virgins; and in few moneths
'Twill brace your bellies ſo hard, that
They ſhall ſound too.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: Now ye ſpeak a Language we underſtand not.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come, I'll interpret.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Madam, you anew create me: I'll neither faile the time, nor place.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: You ſee the power of your Courtſhip, Sir;
Therefore pray impute my yielding to
Your high merit, and not my levity.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: All your actions are ſo bountifull, they
Can admit no bad conſtruction.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I relie upon your nobleneſs, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: I attend your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Tiek.
sp.p: Madam, my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: 'Tis pitty ſuch beauties ſhould go home unaccompanied.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: We are almoſt there; I pray excuſe us.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Lady, ſhall I lead you?

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.l: When I am blinde I'll ſend for you:
A Dog were worth money then.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: I'll follow, though it be but for another jeer.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I muſt crave your patience, for the exchanging of a word or two.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I am your creature, Madam, you may command me.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.l: Do you perceive nothing in this face, that
May inſtruct your memory who I am?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Truſt me, no; yet your beauty would
Challenge a remembrance, though I muſt ſtile
My ſelfe ſo much infortunate, as to
Acknowledge this the ſecond day of our
Acquaintance. —

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: Nay, let us lay by complement, and now
Be ſerious: poſſibly as a ſtranger you may
Not deale ſo faithfully in my ſervice, as
I could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Madam, I do beſeech you credit me
A Gentleman, and that it is not my
Profeſſion to practice ſuch deceit,
Eſpecially unto a beauty of your excellence.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: Truſt me, I cannot be too cautious, Sir,
In what ſo much concernes me as this match,
The onely hope, on which my fortunes have
Dependency: the eſore I thought it good
To let you know, how well I was acquainted
With you once, and deare in your Fathers
Thoughts as you.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: You won't confound me! with me acquainted?
Sure you miſtake the man: for I have been
Abſent from England more then ſeven yeares:
Beſides, my Father, to whom you do pretend
You were ſo deare, is now ſome ten yeares dead;
And then you ſcarce could have the uſe of reaſon.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs all your aſſertions truths,
Which needs muſt verifie what I affirm.
You had a Siſter, whom you did ſend,
Two yeares after your father died, beyond
The Seas for breeding, to a Nunnery,

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: I do remember well that fatall truth.
Madam, for charity do not renew
That loſſes grief. O poore Clariana!
She periſht in the voyage by a wrack,
Which mournefull tidings did ſo much afflict
My heart, I took no comfort in this land,
And thereupon I did reſolve to travell.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: Then for to eaſe you of that grieſe, let me
Aſſure you, that your Siſter ſcap'd the wrack,
Swimming upon a plank to Dovers Sands.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Oh happy news! But know you where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: Do you ſee this Casket?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: It was my Siſters, Madam, left her by our
Mother on her death-bed.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Then know me for that Siſter.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: As ſuch I lovingly embrace you,
And do believ't. One confirmation more;
Let's ſee your arme: 'tis ſo, the very mold.
My deareſt Siſter, welcome.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: I'm glad to ſee you, Brother, and yet ſorry
To ſee you ſtill ſo wilde, theſe courſes in the end
Muſt ruine you.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: No chiding, Siſter; youth will have its ſwindge:
My wilde Oates muſt be ſown, then I'll appeare
As grave as a new-ſhav'd Senator: prethee
Tell me the circumſtance of thy eſcape,
And how thou haſt lived theſe ſeven yeares.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: Honeſt, and ſtill a Maid; let that ſuffice:
The reſt you may know hereafter. But to
Our buſineſs now, concerning Rant.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I wiſh you had made this diſcovery ſooner.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: Why, what makes you look ſo pale? have
You diſcovered my deſign? if ſo, thou haſt
Eternally undone me: for without him,
However to him I have been ſevere,
I cannot live.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Now muſt I lie, or ſhew my ſelf a Raſcall.
Fie, fie, wipe your eyes, be not ſo paſſionate.
As I am an honeſt man, I told him nothing:
But as I was a knave I told him all.
Yet in my opinion there were no great
Loſs of him, conſidering his wilde conditions.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: I am not ignorant of them; yet do not doubt,
My love will teach me patience to reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Why think him then thy own; go in, and
Get a Prieſt in readineſs.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.p: I ſhall obey you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Now have I more buſineſs, then a Lawyer
In a Michaelmas Term, though much leſs time
To effect it; firſt t' oblige the Doctors wiſe
With the manly courteſie of a nights lodging;
The which muſt recompence the hopes I looſe
In this that proves my Siſter; then little
Acuta, ſhe would be nibling too:
The Rogue loves me, yet willingly would have
The cloake of Matrimony caſt o're her luſt:
A fooliſh promiſe, or two, will ſatisfie.
Without a Prieſt, her ſcruples. Then my laſt,
To make a match between my ſiſter and
Sweet Monſieur Rant, will prove my maſter piece:
But I looſe time, which is too precious now,
Fate give my ſiſters love ſucceſs, and then
Though I miſs mine, they can finde other men.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Blunt, Philoſtratus like a phyſitian, Virginio.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: YOur recommendation's good, very good, from a good friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Beſides the friendſhip, Sir, 'tis charity
To be aſſiſtant to a ſtranger. All
I deſire at preſent, is your good word:
And if you chance to know of any perſon
Infirm of any deſperate diſeaſe,
Such as your London-Doctors have given o're,
I doubt not but to cure them, at leaſt
To give them eaſe.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Excellent, a man ſent by providence,
But Sir, ſuch deſperate diſeaſes, on
Your firſt triall, ſhould you miſcarry,
Would quite diſcredit you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: From ſuch hard asks,
Men gaine opinion of what they are:
Upon my life, I'll not diſcredit you;
For I have ſuch prophetick knowledge, Sir,
Of the malignity of each diſeaſe,
That viewing the patient onely, I can gheſs
To a haires breadth, whether the diſeaſe be
Deſperate, or cureable.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: Let me embrace you: I have occaſion
To employ you ſtraight; and if you proſper in't,
You make me yours for ever. I am plaine,
Sir, Blunt as my name; but many that
Expreſs more, may not perhaps reward
Your paines ſo well as I may do.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am not mercenary; if I can do you any
Good, the ſervice will requite it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: The honeſteſt Phyſitian I ere met with!
In ſooth I'll beare you to your patient ſtraight,
A faire one, I'll aſſure you, and my Miſtriſs:
If you cure her, you may command two
Purſes, her fathers and mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You ſpeak nobly.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: And ſee, he comes as ſent for: what cheere,
Forſoot? How doth my Miſtriſs, and your
Daughter? —

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Never worſe, Mr. Blunt, never worſe.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Doth ſhe continue her Fanatick vein?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: No Sir, but worſe, ſhe's wheel'd about to the
Antipodes, turn'd Princeſs in conceit,
And expects ſtrang Embaſſadors from the
King of Morocco, to fetch and Marry her
By Deputie.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Her diſtemper's high; but ſurely caus'd by love.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: A skilfull Doctor, forſooth, new come from Padua, I had provided for your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: You ſhew your love; but ſhe's paſt recovery.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tho' I affect not to be a Trumpet of my skill,
Yet charity compells me to informe you, that
Your Daughter may be curable, if her diſtemper
Be no more then you deliver; nor will it prove
The moſt deſperate cure I have effected.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Good Sir, I do believe you a great Artiſt;
But I'm old and paſſionate: uſe your beſt
Skill; and if you can reſtore her to her
Former ſenſes, make you your own conditions,
My purſe ſhall ſeal them.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not for your Money, Sir; but for the Love
I bear this Gentleman, and's honoured friend,
Who recommended me unto him, I'll do
My beſt, and that I hope will make you bleſs
Your Stars you ere imploy'd me. I deſire
I may have liberty, and all things elſe
Provided the cure may require—

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Nothing ſhall be wanting. But we delay: come, Mr. Blunt, 'tis time we were about it.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Come, good Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Sir. I follow.

div.head: Scoena Secunda.
div.stage: Acuta with a Letter, and Gliſterpipe, Clittomeſtra.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: CArry this Letter to my Mother, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Gliſ.
sp.l: Fine, and familiar; good ſigns of affection!
I muſt be diligent; from whence comes it?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: That I know not: a Porter left it here even now:
Diſpatch't, and give't my Mother; it may require
A haſty anſwer.

sp.speaker: Gliſ.
sp.p: With expedition, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: So, iſ't hit, I'm made: altho't hinder
My Fathers making, I mean a horned Beaſt,
It may make me a wife, preſerve my mother
Honeſt; theſe are the vertuous ends to which
I fram'd that Letter as from Ticket. Virtue,
As thou doſt know my ends are juſt, ſo give
Succeſs to my deſigns. See, here ſhe comes,
Hooded and mask't. So, ſo; my plot hath hit.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Daughter, I am going a little way: if in my abſence Your Father ſhould return, ſay I was ſent for to a womans labour.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: Or rather, that you are gone unto a man's.
But you forget your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Cilt.
sp.l: Piſh, I finde he's an inconſtant man; I think
Not on him now.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.p: In that y'are wiſe; I told you ſo at firſt.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: My buſineſs requires haſte: farewel, Acuta.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: Farewel, dear mother: if the empty Air
Be pleaſant food to feed your longing with,
Your luſtful appetite may ſurfeit on't:
I grudge it not. How ſlily cunning ſhe
Appear'd in hiding from me what my ſelf
Deſigned, onely to fruſtrate her wicked ends!
But I with Monſieur Ticket will keep touch,
And meet him at his own appointed place,
In the More-fields, the whilſt my mother
At Iſlington doth feaſt her ſelf on hopes,
And eat Stew'd-Pruands for reſtoratives.
Ha, ha, he! the fancy how it pleaſes me
But I muſt to my task; ſhe gains a prize
That picks a vertuous Husband out of vice.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: HOw doſt feel thy ſelf?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: This wench hath given me a ſhrew'd hearing; my brains begin to turn like tumblers, and do the Summerſet in my ſcull: I wonder ſhe continues ſober.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Cuſtom hath rendred it a ſecond nature to her: but by my faith, friend, you ſhall drink no more, ſince it doth ſo diſturb you.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Piſh, 'tis nothing: a little heats me.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: If 't be no more, you'll do your work the better, a little wins the ſoule of Venery, and makes a man all fancy. But did'ſt thou marke with what a canonicall countenance and ceremony the fellow ſeem'd to marry you? he lookt ſo ſuperciliouſly, I ſcarce knew him for my man.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Faith he would have deceiv'd any: but to ſee
The wench, ſhe ſtands upon it now, as
If ſhe were ſome Votary: ſhe won't go to bed
Forſooth at undecent houres, and brides it
As much as my Lady Mayoreſs at a Coronation.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: But the jeſt will be, boy, after thou haſt
Enjoy'd her, and I my promiſe (for we muſt
Not diſcover before) what a pickle ſhe'll
Be in! —

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he! the pretty faces ſhe'll make!

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.p: VVhen ſhe findes her ſelfe deluded, by being our whore, in ſtead of your wife, by my faith a great deſcent.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Certainly ſhe'll gaule her tongue with ſcolding,
And batter down the wall of her mouth,
I meane her teeth, with the thunderbolt
Of her exclaimes.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Nay, we muſt expect lightening too; for ſhe's
A Serpent, and can ſpit fire.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Howere, I'll ſtand her boldly; I believe the
Breach is made to my hand. But now we
Talke of broken commodities, art not thou
To meet the Doctors wife to night?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I am; but I'll ſee thee incircled within Aſtutia's armes firſt, and then I'm for her.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Faith Ticket I muſt have a reverſion there; 'tis
Juſtice, Wench for Wench: beſides, thou art to
Have a taſte of my red Deare; and Veniſon is
A meat to pleaſure friends with.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Marry here, I take pains for you, and my
Selfe too; in th' other venter, for my ſelfe
Onely: and could'ſt thou have the conſcience
To reap the harveſt of all my labours,
And never take pains to ſowe?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Deare Ticket, I onely deſire the gleanings, and thoſe are allowed to idle perſons: then conſider who entred you into that acquaintance: good turnes would be remembred.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: And ſhall: if this wench can't allay your heat, th'other's at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: VVhy now thou ſpeak'ſt nobly, like a worthy engroſſer of Mutton: but mum, here comes my mock-bride; oh ſhe paces admirably well!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: She'll trot and jolt anon: a through-pac'd wench, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Sweet, are you come to haſten me to bed?

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: The nights are long, Sir, and you may no doubt
Finde time enough, before Aurora doth
Unvaile her face, to make you weary of
Thoſe ſports your expectation flatters you
Withall: Marriage is a holy thing,
And all it's Rites, Sir, are to be perform'd
With ceremonious and due reſpect.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: But Deare, the Ceremony now is o're:
Since that the Prieſt hath ti'd our hands, and love
Our hearts; what can remaine, but that we taſte
Thoſe lawfull ſweets, which Hymen doth allow
His votaries?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Madam, indeed 'tis late; for night begins
To ſpread her ſable Canopy o'er the Earth.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: Sir, I am all obedience: if it be
Your pleaſure thus early to go to reſt,
I am your ſervant now, and muſt obey:
All that before I ſaid, I pray excuſe:
A fond deſire to retaine a while
My Virgin-ſtate, reprieve my Maiden-head,
Made me contend; no diſobedience
To your will, which ever ſhall be mine
In all that's good, or but indifferent;
So ſtrictly knit to yours, that none therein,
Though envy lent them eyes, ſhall ere diſcerne
A difference.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: What pity 'tis ſhe is a whore!
Were ſhe honeſt, and thus obedient,
She would grow up a Preſident for wives,
And be a woman born to make men happy.
But ſhe is light, and therefore ſhun'd the light:
For whil'ſt day peept, her deeds of darkneſs
Durſt not ſhew their face, nor ſhew her luſt.
Why do I terme it ſo? to me 'tis not:
For ſhe enjoyes a husband in her thoughts,
Whil'ſt I do knowingly embrace a VVhore;
Yet is her promiſe to my friend no wayes
Excuſable; ſee, ſhe drives the bargain:
A man were well holp up with ſuch a wife:
They toy: 'twas well the Marriage was in jeſt.
I like my armes, and would not change my creſt.
Deare, let's not waſte ſuch precious time: to bed,
There let us looſe our ſelves in one another,
And raiſe our pleaſures up to ſuch a height,
The gods themſelves may envy at our bliſs.
Come, is the Poſſet made?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: To what purpoſe? here are no aged Matrons to mumble the curd between their gumms, and read a baudy lecture to your bride, till laughter makes them foame at mouth again. A Poſſet? none but an Antiquary would have ask't for ſuch an apocryphall meate, as antient as Rebellion it ſelfe. Faith a Tub full of graines will be as rich geere to make a Protectorian frollick, and liquor Sattin Gownes with.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Thou art ſuch a modiſh Zealot, and ſuch an
Enemy to old faſhions and cuſtomes, I wonder
Thou loveſt women ſo, a thing in faſhion
In old Adam's dayes.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: And ſo were Cloaths; yet ſtill their faſhion
Changes; ſo nature varies beauties; ſometimes
Long viſages are à la mode, ſometimes round, then
Broad, triangle, ovall; any forme that is
In preſent uſe, and moſt eſteeme, fancie
Decrees for faireſt.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Thy reaſons are unanſwerable: I ſubmit,
And will ſteale as ſilently to bed as a Zealot
To his brothers wife when he's aſleep.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Get you gone then and be naught together;
You looſe much time. Had I ſo ſweet a Bride,
I would prevent the morning, which within
Few houres will appeare to chide your dulneſs.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Faith we're to blame: come, deare, let's in
To bed, for feare the God of Marriage grow
Incens'd. — Ticket, good reſt, and pleaſing dreames.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: You have the pleaſing ſubſtance, Sir, make
Much on't. So, this happily is diſpatch't:
Now to my Doctors wife; I hope ſhe'll prove,
Though not a lawfull, a ſweet prize of love.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: SHe's extreamly tainted, Sir, that's certain;
And her diſtemper ſtill growes higher.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I ſee it does, Sir, to my griefe I ſee it.
Never was man like me unfortunate,
T'have but one childe, one comfort in my age,
And to have her diſtracted, mad. Heavens,
How did my youth offend, that on my age
You do inflict ſo cruell and ſevere
A puniſhment?

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Have patience, forſooth: Mr. Doctor, ſpeak ſome comfort to him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I wiſh I could; and yet I don't deſpaire
But that time and healing medicaments
May cure her diſtemper, and reſtore
The Lady to her priſtine health.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Oh! never Sir, 'tis not within
The power of art, to render me ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Oh ſweet Miſtriſs Coelia!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, be of cheere, I may have yet in ſtore
Something may comfort her. Alaſs, I pitty you,
And participate your grief: we muſt have time
To obſerve and marke her ſeverall diſtempers;
For each diſtraction hath its ſeveral cauſe,
And every cauſe produceth an effect,
By which 'tis known; and a diſeaſe once known,
You know's halfe cured.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: VVould hers were ſo: the little hope I've left
Is in your art, pray uſe your utmoſt skill.
Command me and my purſe for a reward.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir, if my life would cure her, I would not ſet a price on't; but let's obſerve, ſhe comes, and in her fit.

div.stage: Enter Coelia, richly, but phantaſtically habited: Servants.

sp.speaker: Coelia.
sp.p: Set us our Chaire of State, and o're our head erect a Chryſtall Canopy, all full of Diamond-ſtars, whoſe luſtre may blinde bleere-ey'd Aſtronomers to gaze upon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: In her Princely ſtraine, we muſt obſerve her geſtures and her ſpeech, and calculate by them the cauſe of her diſtemper.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Let me alone to watch; I'll be as vigilant, as an Informer in Lent.

sp.speaker: Coelia.
sp.l: Me thinks our Court's too meane, not rich enough
To entertain the love of ſuch a Prince.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Love is one cauſe, marke that.

sp.speaker: Coelia.
sp.l: But we will have moſt glorious ornaments;
Our walls and pavements all of beaten gold;
Love in a fiery chariot ſhall deſcend,
And with his flaming beames tranſpierce his heart,
VVhil'ſt I on gaudy Iris back aſcend
The clouds, and gloriouſly eclipſe the Sun.
How can my love be abſent? — hark, hark,
I heare him come in Charles VVaine, lumbring
Through the Clouds, before we are prepar'd.
Turrets and Galleries we muſt have built;
And Arches carv'd in one intire ſtone.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mark the effects of pride; yet ſtill relating to her love.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Poor Coelia!

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Pillars of Pearle, and lofty Pyramids
Of Diamonds, upon whoſe ſpires ſhall be
Erected, with ſacred and myſterious art,
A Saphire proſpect to orelook the world.
Next, will I have a heaven made of Chryſtall,
And womens hearts all adamant; the mens
Vulcan ſhall forge of his refined ſteele,
That they cleave in one and never part.
'Tis well you know your diſtance. See my commands
Be executed all, you are my ſurveyor. —

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: She cooles, and growes more temperate.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Why ſhould I not have him, him that I love?
Obedience, love, duty, affections;
Oh you diſcordant contrarieties!
What a confuſion do you breed within
My fancie, and keep a ſtrugling for the
Maſterſhip!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now ſhe diſcourſes ſomewhat ſenſibly;
Her rank diſtemper certainly is love,
My art much fails me elſe; which not enjoy'd,
Worſe frenzie followes, in the end her death,
Which Phyſicks skill wants power to prevent.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: It is too incredible to gain belief:
Yet with my heart I wiſh it were no worſe,
Then might I hope a remedy, which now
Alas is deſperate. She love! poor Girl,
Love knows not ſuch an enemy as her:
She hath with tears beſought me on her knees,
When I've preſented Husbands to her choice,
That I'd diſpence with her obedience,
And leave her to her Virgin-happineſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs 'tis ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: And when, forſooth, I offer'd my love, and ſervice,
You would not think, forſooth, how ſhe ſlighted it!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: All that may be, Sir; y'are inclin'd to age;
And poſſibly the lovers tender'd by
This Gentleman unto his daughters choice
And liking, little agreeable unto
The Ladies fancy, which is the womb of love.
You may believe me Maſter of a confidence
That ſorts not with true art, to build upon
Conjectural ſpeculations: But when
You ſhall underſtand my chiefeſt skill lies
In Phyſiognomy, which is the Index
Of the Minde, that through obſervation
I have learnt the radical cauſe of ſuch
Diſtempers, you cannot blame me if I deſire
You would bethink your ſelf, or have her askt
Concerning theſe particulars.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Theſe three years I dare anſwer for her: indeed ſome four years ſince I do remember a proper Gentleman, but much in his eſtate decayed, made tenders of his love; I therefore thought him not a match for her, no more did ſhe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If it might not be too great boldneſs, I ſhould crave his name.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: He call'd himſelf Philoſtratus.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Philoſtratus! he is not here; why do
You mock me thus? yet he is too unkind
That will not come and ſee his Coelia die.
My ſoul is fleeting in an Airy Chariot.
Directly to Elyzium; but I'll
Soon return, and hant my Philoſtratus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now you'll approve my art.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: 'Tis more then humane!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Her infirmitie's plain: if you eſteem her life at any rate, you may preſerve it.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Value her life! oh, Sir, don't queſtion it:
Were Philoſtratus poorer then he is,
And that his marriage could but cure her;
I'd embrace his alliance with more joy
Then if Croeſus ſtore flow'd in his Coffers.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: I hope you will not make an Aſs of me,
Forſooth, I have your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Always provided that you got her conſent: which not obtain'd, my promiſe, Sir, is void. Good Mr. Doctor, inquire out this man, this philoſtratus; let us not neglect the means that may reſtore her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, I go:
But would be willingly aſſur'd before,
That you will ratifie the match: for
Tho' he's a ſtranger to me, I'd be loth
To do a Gentleman ſuch injury,
As to revive an almoſt-quencht affection.
With hopes, that would not prove realities.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Oh doubt it not! I love my child too well:
Yet to confirm your faith, liſt to my vow:

l.hi: If that the Gods reſtore my child to health,

sp.l: By means of Philoſtratus, or his love;
I ſwear by Styx, that oath of dreadful awe

l.hi: Amongſt the Gods, which they durſt never break,

sp.l: Philoſtratus ſhall have my full conſent
To take her for his Wife: of which fixt vow
Heaven and you are witneſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, and now crave performance.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Are you Philoſtratus?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The ſame, Sir,; and for your Daughter,
With this kiſs I cure her diſtemper.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I am all wonder!

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: And I all fool, to bring a Doctor to wipe my noſe.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: Your pardon, gratious father; it was love
That made me counterfeit this Lunacie.
To gain your free conſent, and yet preſerve
My duty and obedience.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I am ſo glad to ſee thee thus recover'd,
I want wards to expreſs my joy:
But take him, Girl, thou haſt deſerv'd him well.
Philoſtratus, I need not doubt thy love,
Which hath continued ſo many years
(Almoſt without hope) conſtant: ſuch love
Muſt proſper; take her, Philoſtratus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Welcome, dear bleſſing: with far greater joy
Do I receive thee into my boſome,
Then malefactors at their deaths reprieves.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.l: My joy's too great to be expreſs'd in words;
My fancie and my love too high. The Gods
Affect not heaven more then I Philoſtratus:
For which rich gifts (deare Father) I do owe
You more, then for my birth.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: And may the gift be worth it, and thou him:
The promiſes are fair on both ſides. Let's
To Church, and ſolemnize your loving Rites.
Mr. Blunt, come, cheere up, man; thou wert
My choice, but none can war with fate:
Howe're, be merry at the Wedding, man;
There be more wives i'th' world.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And here comes one of equall years to fit him.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Sweet Coelia!

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: My Governeſs, and dripping! ſure ſhe hath been new dipt.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: For love of you: but I'll make no more diſcoveries: a preciſe Raſcall, like an unconſcionable villain as he was, ſet me upon a tub of water for a ſtoole of repentance, upon which my devotion cooling, I fell aſleep; and • odding, tilted backwards into the water; up went my heeles and ſo I made a diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Of the Netherlands.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If you be a charitable man, warme this piece of devotion; that is, marry her; ſhe'd prove both a Wiſe and a Nurſe: the laſt you want moſt.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: I would do much, I can tell you, to get even with you: I have been fob'd of one wife already.

sp.speaker: Coel.
sp.p: You may venter here with ſafety, with aſſurance: none will rob you of her; and I am ſure my Governeſs is kinde-hearted.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: I would not forgoe a good turne; but I am glad to ſee you come to ſo well, Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Come, let it be a Match, and all to Church together.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I ſee he's well inclin'd: ſilence conſents. You'll have 〈◊〉 cleane Bride of her, ſhe hath been well waſh't.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Oh that Raſcall! could I but light on him. —

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Do not raile upon him; he has almoſt done you that good in ſatisfaction, by procuring you a rich Churle for a
Husband, as may make you bleſs him all dayes of your life.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Was it you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No matter; I, or one in my Coat: at dinner I'll relate all paſſages.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I do ſuſpect mad prankes. Son, take your Bride.
May nought but death this union divide.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Nay, Miſtriſs, we'll make up the ſecond couple; a Compleate match, i' faith.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Why well ſaid, Neighbour, now I like it; you go Roundly to the louſineſs.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: I can do it home, I can tell you.
You will make an obedient wife?

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Yes, and pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is right Love, and Courtſhip A la mode.
Lady, will you Marry me? yes Sir, with all my
Heart: but for obedience, you ſhould have left it
Till you came to Church, where ſhe perhaps would have
Left it behinde her.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: We looſe much time: come, Lovers let's away;
For Hymen's Ri • es admit of no delay.

div.head: Scoena Quinta.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: My Wife! I ſcorn't: thou common Waſtecoateer,
And mercenary receipt for luſt, do'ſt think
I had ſo little wit to marry thee?
Thou poore abuſed foole.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: I thought you had more honeſty, then to
Deny your Wife; at leaſt more Manhood, then
To uſe her ſcurvily, unlike your ſelfe.
You know I am no whore; you had my Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Yes, the nineteenth reverſion: do I
Not know your tricks to couſen men,
Your ſurphling water, and a thouſand more,
Which I conceale for modeſty?
Or be it granted that thou wert a Maide,
Will that ſtrengthen a Marriage made in ſport,
By a poore ſilly ſerving-man?

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: I ſtill am patient; but much I feare
You'll finde it otherwiſe: and when you know
That I am Tickets Siſter, a pure Virgin,
That never yet knew one diſhoneſt thought,
Nor any crime, but too much love to you,
Sure you'll repent my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: How, Ticket's Siſter! how dar'ſt thou thus
Abuſe me, abuſe my friend, and know
Thou haſt a life within my power?
Oh impudence of women! did'ſt thou not
Promiſe him to make this match?
The neareſt courteſie that woman e're
Afforded man.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: I did, yet with no bad intent, knowing
I could at any time acquit my ſelfe,
By letting him know I was his Siſter.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Still doſt perſiſt in thy moſt damned untruths?
I would my friend were here, that we might take
A full revenge upon thy impudence.
How now? the news.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I have a Letter to your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: The contents will notifie.

body.p: Deare Brother (for ſo my Siſter now hath made you) I deſire yours and her company inſtantly at the Popes head in Morefields, where I ſhall largely ſatisfie you of all particular stouching your Marriage: you have got a noble Gentlewoman, uſe her as ſhe deſerves, nobly; uſe her as my ſiſter, lovingly, as you will preſerve the good opinion of

div.l: Short, and ſweet! I am Married, it ſeems;
Jugled into Matrimony without
My knowledge; a VVedding A la mode.
Brother Ticket, if you are not really
My brother, but have Married me to one
Of your Aunts; here's that ſhall do me reaſon:
And Lady Bride, your policy ſhall ſmart for't.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: But if you finde I really am ſo,
Siſter to Ticket, and a wife to you;
VVhat ſatisfaction ought you then to make
My innocence, for ſo abuſing me,
Abuſing her, that lov'd you, lov'd you
Beyond reaſon, beyond meaſure?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: If thou prov'ſt all this, I will forgive thee,
And that's a favour, becauſe thou married'ſt me
VVithout my owne conſent: 'twas plaguy neate,
A cleane conveyance, carried on with wit:
I fancy it hugely, and I fear I ſhall love thee;
For I begin to have a good conceit
Of thy honeſty: me thought my laſt
Nights lodging ſmick't and ſavour'd of the maidenhead.
Let's to thy brother now, if he be ſo;
He ſhall be ſtill my friend, if not, my foe.

sp.speaker: Aſtu.
sp.l: He will confirme this truth, and that you are
My lawfull husband, that I won you faire.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: MEthinks 'tis a fine freſh air.

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: I am weary of air; I would have ſome reality.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Thou'dſt have thou knowſt not what. Have I not vow'd a thouſand times that I love thee? ſworn Oaths that would induce an Atheiſt to belief? Nay, have I not proffer'd to ſtamp my ſeal upon the virgin-wax? what wouldſt have more?

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: I'd have thee honeſt, that is, make good thy vows,
And marry me: thou ſeeſt the hazards I
Have run, to ſave my mothers honour, and
Thy ſoul; hazarded my own dear fame
What think you Rumour will deliver of me?
What ſevere cenſures men will paſs upon me,
And juſtly too, for meeting of you here?
It doth, I muſt confeſs, exceed the bounds
Of modeſty; but when the world ſhall know,
I came to ſave the honour of my houſe,
You in my mother ſought to undermine,
To tell you, how baſe a diſſembler you are,
In ſpite of love, here to renounce all love
That is not warranted both by the Laws
Of Church and State; then, Ticket, the world
Will know my innocence, and thy guilt.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: They'll know your love too (Lady) that was the cauſe (however you diſguiſe it) of this viſitation.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: I value not who knows it, I confeſs it;
And therein glory, I can maſter it.
She ne'er was virtuous, that was never tempted;
I have ſtood the ſhock of both, of love and of
Temptation; yet know, thou great diſſembler,
My virtue's ſuch, that had I not power to
Reſiſt thy love, before I'd yeild to any
Looſe embrace, I'd ſhew my ſelf a Lucrece,
And die Virtues Martyr.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: I do admire thee! fair virtuous ſoul,
If thou canſt pardon my paſt wandering love,
And think me worthy of thee, I am thine.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: Adde not unto my injuries; was't not
Enough to court me to affection firſt,
And then to work upon my weakneſs,
By tempting me to luſt; but now when I
Have overcome thy luſt and my affection,
Again to enſnare me, on pretence of marriage?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Let not my paſt errours beget obduracie
In your belief; if now I do not mean it
Really, let goodneſs in my greateſt need
Forſake me: witneſs theſe tears.

sp.speaker: Gamb.
sp.p: Never was man ſo tormented as I; firſt to be catcht up in a Whirlewinde, and hurried I know not where; them coming home, to miſs my Wife, my Daughter, and my man: Oh my brains, my head, my horrid monſtrous head! I feel my temples ſprout, they ſpread, they ſpread; give me patience, give me patience.

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: I do believe you, Sir, you are to me
More welcome now in your return to love,
To faithful love I mean, then if
You had never err'd.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: You anew create my hopes, and ſee
Your father to compleat the match.

sp.speaker: Gamb.
sp.l: Oh my eys! am I aſleep, or do I wake?
My Daughter at an Alehouſe window?
Plague of the Devil, my Wife's upon the
Bed: Oh my torments! my helliſh torments;
They gnaw my heart-ſtrings. Strumpet,
What make you there?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Tho' you be her father, yet give me leave
To tell you y'are foul-mouth'd: ſhe's ſo chaſte,
She knows not what your language means:
She's a Mine of Virtue; you may glory
In having th' honour to call her daughter;
She hath made me a convert, made
Clean a Leopard.

sp.speaker: Gamb.
sp.p: May I believe her virtuous? a Virgin ſtill!

sp.speaker: Acut.
sp.l: Father, let my tears perſwade you to
Believe it, not ſhed for any guilt,
But to ſoften your obdurate heart.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Riſe, ſweet; waſte not in vain thoſe pearly drops:
Let me alone to juſtifie
Thy virtue 'gainſt the world; firſt, Sir, to you,
Who are more jealous far then wiſe:
This Lady, tho' your daughter, is now my wife;
Nor can your jealous humour injure her,
But I participate the calumny,
Therefore bound to vindicate her virtue:
She ne'er had won me for a Husband,
If by intreaties, proteſtations, oaths,
Gold, Jewels or other allurements
I could have entred her Virgin-fort.
In farther addition to her glory, know,
She was your chiefe preſerver from abuſe;
For I'll confeſs my crimes, becauſe I meane
Amendment: I courted long your wife.

sp.speaker: Gamb.
sp.l: I am a Cuckold irrecoverably, too ſenſibly
I feele it. Oho!

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.l: You ſeeme diſturb'd; i' faith you have no cauſe,
Thanks to your daughter. After long courtſhip,
I obtain'd a triviall favour of your wife,
To give me here a meeting; which ſhe'd done
If not prevented by your daughter, who ſent
Her Mother to waite at Iſlington my coming.

sp.speaker: Gam.
sp.p: Oh how am I bleſt in a virtuous Childe!

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: You are indeed, and in a virtuous wife,
If that your jealouſie do not corrupt her;
For none but ſhe could have ſo long withſtood
The various traines I laid to blow her
Virtue up.

sp.speaker: Gam
sp.l: VVell then, farewell it; I ſee 'tis a folly
To be jealous of what we can't prevent.
Daughter, I crie thee mercy for my ill
Opinion of thee; nay, I'll buy it with
Five hundred pounds more then I meant
Thee. Son, thou appear'ſt a Gentleman;
Take my conſent: I give thee my daughter
VVillingly, provided thou wilt not feek
To cuckold the father.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I ſhall ever pay the love and duty of a Son.

sp.speaker: Gam.
sp.p: Why well ſaid Son; where ſhall we keep the wedding?

sp.speaker: Acu.
sp.p: If it be your pleaſure, I think at Iſlington, where my Mother expects us.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Come, ſweet, let's thither; the Parſon of the Village ſhall confirme the bargain, and ſo to bed.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Brother Ticket, well met.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: I wiſh you joy, Sir: nay, never frowne; ſhe is my ſiſter, a Gentlewoman; and tho' her portion's ſmall, her love deſerves you, and ſo I thought it a part of friendſhip to bring you together. I dealt not worſe by you then I have done by my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: VVhat, married?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: As you ſee, —
Going to be ti'd to the ſweet Apple-tree.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p:
Nay, I'll never ſpoile mirth: here's my hand, I
thought to have raged extreamly, but it ſhall be like a loving brot 〈…〉 wiſh you joy.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: VVhy God-a-mercy; the like to thee.

sp.speaker: Gam.
sp.p: And I wiſh joy to both.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.l: Thanks, worthy Father; now let's to Iſlington
To conſummate my Vow, and after feaſt
There with our Mother: you ſhall be my gueſt.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: But ſee how opportunely come new friends, and from a wedding too! we are going to the place from whence you came.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Two VVeddings meet! why this is luck i' faith.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: And we make up the third Couple.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.p: Nay feakins, forſooth, we make up the meſs.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Happy beyond our wiſh! let's in a meaſure celebrate our joyes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: VVith all our hearts.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: OƲr Lovers Courtſhip, held no common road:
In France it was conceiv'd, Love à la mode,
French novelties ſtill uſe to pleaſe our Nation,
Better then any Engliſh home-ſpun Faſhion;
Which makes us hope, that this our Play will hit,
Being made to the Meridian of your wit:
Yet for all this, we have juſt cauſe to feare,
All are not faſhion-mongers that are here:
And thoſe that be, do change the Mode ſo faſt,
We are afraid, our wit can never laſt
Above a Terme; which did our Poet move,
To finiſh all in Matrimonial love;
That love is antient, and muſt ever laſt;
I would your loves were knit to us as faſt:
That of our Authors Muſe you may beget
Never, and better off-ſprings of his wit.
